There are many times that I wish I could turn back the clock to be able to witness many events. When I heard about the launch, All I thought about was, "Ok there's now a Tesla orbiting earth. Big woop." I didn't know at the time, mankind had achieved something great. Mankind achieved the impossible. Now two years later, watching the footage of the launch here on youtube, seeing Falcon Heavy's engines roar to life, carrying it into the heavens gave me chills. It brought me back to when I was younger. A time where little ol' me was so invested in everything space, watching The Universe on TV on the weekends instead of watching cartoons, the surprise trip to the Kennedy Space Center and the Johnson Space Center in Houston that my parents took me to, looking up towards the heavens through a telescope, wearing my NASA hat with pride (which I still have and wear to this day), and wishing to become an astronaut. Memories like those bring a smile to my face. I wish I could have seen that launch live on TV, feeling the excitement and pride that all the employees of SpaceX felt that day.


To this day, I will keep this monumental event in mind every time I hear a distant roar from outside my own home. Because out there, outside of that small town of McGregor, TX, one man and his company are paving the way the future of space technology and exploration.

I must admit I didn't know much about SpaceX up until recently.
When I watched the launch of FH and then saw the booster rockets COME BACK TO EARTH AND LAND????? I was literally screaming. WHAT THE F**K over and over again- and loudly. My sons raced into the room to see what I was screaming about.
After the shock I showed them.. they were shocked too.
All my life I assumed booster rockets were lost in space forever.
I'm 56, so you can imagine my surprise when the FH booster rockets returned to earth. It was pure magic to see.. like a well choreographed ballet of machinery.
Thank you Elon for this.. I'm like a little girl again when I watch spaceX launches.

I remember the July 1969 lunar landing. It was a school day and the whole school sat in the main room to watch it on a rather small black and white tv (as that was all we had back then)
I went home for lunch as I lived across the road and stayed home - watched it on the tv. We were allowed to as the staff acknowledged that it was a special day.
I remember it well. If I look for it, I will show you the newspaper from that day which had a front page pic of the landing on the moon.

Bravo, sir! This truly is a work of art. I've been following you for awhile now, and can't believe I just stumbled upon this. Absolutely busy. As a fellow space nerd and musician, this hits so many emotions for me.

Very well done - this is a beautiful composition, and "commissioning" it for the inaugural FH launch is just such an awesome concept. From a fellow "everyday astronaut" to another - keep up the awesome work, and keep those videos coming. Cheers, Tim!

Tim, your music carries the mood and excitement of this fantastic launch. Thank you so much for all you do to foster the continued interest of so many people in space. Love your broadcasts of all the launches but this one is special.
I had tears in my eyes and cheered each part of the launch and then the landing of the two boosters, right on the 'X', in tandem was the cherry on top. The first look at the spaceman and his Tesla made me laugh with joy.
I've seen lots of launches but this one was special. It was as emotional as Apollo 11 but the fact it was being done by a private company run by an entrepreneur who was not sure it would be successful and had been advertised in the open media really moved me. American ingenuity and flair. Elon Musk restarted interest in space and high goals that had languished in America and if for no other reason came alive. He is to be saluted. The man is a genius.
Your music is the pulse of SpaceX and the American dream of humanity, a limitless future!

Honestly I don't know why they don't just delay the footage 30 seconds and have storage onboard which can record the hole launch sequence and dynamically change the bitrate so that if it loses connection temporarily you should usually not see any cut outs as you would be sending it in packets, so if a packet or or a group of packets doesn't make it then then you can simply rerequest them and by delaying the broardcast by 30 second or maybe even a minute you can give time for even the latency of doing that to not be a problem. And they can pull the full quality video from the craft after the fact.

It's not like storage is that heavy nowerdays a 512GB microSD would be enough to do it even if it's losses video although in that case your limitation would be bandwidth, but given that they are almost certainly compressing the video anyway to be sent by satellite

Listening to this on a loop as I do my Calculus 1 homework for my Aerospace Engineer Degree! Last year I had just been medically retired from the Army, and didn't really have a good plan on what I was going to do with my life. I've always been a big space nerd so I was excited to watch this live, but I had no idea just how much it would effect my life. As soon as the fairings separated I knew I wanted to do with my life, and I signed up for the summer semester at ACC. Now I'm into my 3rd semester and loving it, and can't wait to transfer to a 4 year university (hopefully UT). Love your songs, videos, and livestreams, keep up the great work!

Trivia: The above video and the official video linked in description is not actually the original live stream video. There was a mistake with the live stream and the video feed for the side boosters was for the same booster, initially the streaming staff didn't think this was the case and were adamant about it despite both feeds appearing to be the exact same, it was chalked up to both sides mirroring the other, which would make sense, except as we now know both sides use the same parts so they are not mirrored, which makes more sense from a build standard. however, by the end of the stream when the rockets were landing, it became obvious it was the same feed as anyone familiar with the landing pads knew they both looked different and on the stream they were both landing on the same exact pad and they both had another rocket to their left.... within 24 hours the stream was pulled and replaced with the correct footage. Im not sure if anyone even has the original footage anymore, there really wasn't any point to keep it and no reason to think spacex would get rid of it, I never would have thought they kept all original footage from each camera and would be able to rebuild it.

Additional trivia: The landing cut outs on the barge are not actually real, they are done on purpose. everyone loves to see landings but seeing something go boom can take away from the attention the primary mission gets, souring the mood for those watching(when they should be celebrating!) and with media coverage its just bad PR. this lets them avoid that which is honestly quite understandable, before spacex there wasn't anyone showing launches and landings like they do, so its not shown initially until they are sure the stage landed safely. Its worth noting however that they are not shy about showing them go boom, they have an entire blooper reel on their youtube page showing all of the landing failures. The landing cut was revealed and never acknowledged as far as im aware, during one of the live streams. you could see the landing footage live streaming on a screen in the background despite the split screen showing the live stream had dropped out.
Love that this has the two side by/side views corrected!

Tim --
I want to thank you for everything that you do. It was one year ago today, watching the Falcon Heavy launch that got me into space, and rockets in general. After the launch, I was doing research and found you.

Your videos are of the highest quality, and can inspire anyone to go into this field. Watching this video, in the Falcon Heavy shirt, with Falcon Heavy posters everywhere in my room, listening to this amazing music is truly an honor.

I think this reinforces that space is meant to bring us together, and that it has.

Thank you for all of the videos, the live streams, and for bringing space down to everyday people. I wish the best of luck to you,
Trevor.
(P.S: FALCON HEAVY IN MARCH, and Crew Dragon right around the corner. Can't wait!!)

There is just something about rocket launches that makes your hearth scip for a second. The flashing of the sparks, the rumbling of the engines as they eject tons of gases against the ground in order to achieve the ultimate goal of sending just a fraction of this massive objects weight onto its lonely journey around our blue home.

“The scale of it all” has to be my favorite.  It’s the kind of musical atmosphere that I’ve always associated with space.  I have no idea why.  I have a whole Spotify playlist for sleep with this kind of relaxing, atmospheric music and every single track evokes images of nebulae, stars, planets, supernovae, and thousands of galaxies much like Hubble’s iconic photos.
Man this is absolutely awesome. You do good work. Can't wait for the next Falcon Heavy launch!
